diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 38-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of abdominal pain that has been gradually worsening over the past three months. The pain is located in her upper abdomen and sometimes radiates to her back. She describes the pain as a 4 out of 10 in terms of severity and is worse after meals. She also reports that taking acetaminophen helps to alleviate the pain. She has no recent travel history and has no family history of celiac disease or colon cancer. She has a past medical history of asthma, which is poorly controlled despite regular use of inhaled salbutamol and corticosteroids. She has no history of surgeries and does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports that her diet has not changed significantly in the past three months.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient appears to be in moderate distress. She is tender in the right upper quadrant and has guarding. There is no rebound tenderness or costovertebral angle tenderness. Her bowel and bladder are normal. Her cardiovascular and respiratory exams are normal. Her abdomen is distended with a tender liver and a palpable right iliac fossa mass.
实验室检查：
血常规、尿常规、大便常规、肝功能、肾功能、电解质、肿瘤标志物等实验室检查结果均正常。胃镜检查结果显示胃黏膜无异常，十二指肠球部黏膜未见明显异常。结肠镜检查结果显示回肠末段黏膜未见明显异常，升结肠黏膜未见明显异常。超声检查结果显示肝脏右叶见一大小约4cm×3cm的实性占位，边界不清，内部回声不均，未见明显血流信号。诊断：根据患者的临床表现、实验室检查结果和影像学检查结果，初步诊断为右肝占位性病变，需要进一步进行手术治疗。治疗计划：建议患者进行手术治疗，手术方式为肝脏肿瘤切除术。手术后需要进行化疗和放疗，以减少肿瘤复发的风险。同时，需要定期复查，以监测病情变化。

Text.Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Text.Past Medical History: Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.
Text.Examinations:
Complete blood count shows: white blood cells at 2.46*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 79.0%, lymphocyte percentage at 14.0%, neutrophils count at 1.95*10^9/L, lymphocytes count at 0.34*10^9/L, hemoglobin at 159.00 g/L. 

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.
Text.Diagnosis: 1. Upper gastrointestinal perforation, 2. Cholecystolithiasis, cholecystitis, liver cyst, 3. Thickened ascending colon, 4. Acute diffuse peritonitis
Text.Treatment: Surgical repair of gastric pyloric perforation

Image.00002.jpg: Free air and fluid in the abdominal cavity, blurred fat stranding in the intestinal lumen, suggesting hollow visceral perforation. 2. Liver cyst 3. Gallstones, cholecystitis 4. Thickened ascending colon, further examination recommended

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 66-year-old male presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that had lasted for one day. The patient reported that the pain was located in the right upper quadrant and was accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The patient denied any recent travels or significant changes in his diet or lifestyle. He also denied any family history of gastrointestinal disorders or other medical conditions that may be relevant to his current symptoms. The patient reported that he had a history of gastric ulcers for three years, which he had been treating intermittently with oral medications. The patient denied having hypertension, diabetes, or any other major health issues.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient was found to be normotensive, with a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. The patient was alert and oriented, with no signs of distress. The patient's abdomen was soft, with no guarding or rebound tenderness. There was no evidence of peritonitis or rebound tenderness. The patient's bowel and bladder were normal.
Blood Work:
The patient's complete blood count showed a white blood cell count of 2.46*10^9/L, with a neutrophil percentage of 79.0%, a lymphocyte percentage of 14.0%, and a neutrophil count of 1.95*10^9/L. The patient's biochemical report indicated a total protein level of 45.7 g/L, an albumin level of 22.9 g/L, and a globulin level of 23.60 g/L.
Endoscopy:
The patient was scheduled for an endoscopy, but the results were normal.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is possible that the patient has a gastrointestinal infection or a peptic ulcer. However, to confirm this diagnosis, additional medical examinations such as a blood test or an endoscopy would be necessary.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was advised to continue taking his oral medications for his gastric ulcers, and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and management of his symptoms. The patient was also advised to avoid eating spicy or fatty foods, and to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration. The patient was also advised to avoid alcohol and smoking, as these can irritate the stomach and worsen symptoms.

diagnosis_self:
Case Report
Patient: 31-year-old male with upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The patient consumed a high-fat diet last night and has no past experiences of similar symptoms or family history of digestive issues. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated at 15.14 x 10^9/L, triglycerides are high at 9.44 mmol/L, and electrolyte levels are within normal range. The patient's liver and kidney functions are normal, and calcitonin levels are normal. A CT scan image of the patient's abdomen shows a large mass in the area of the pancreas and surrounding organs.
Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms and medical history, along with the results of diagnostic tests and the CT scan image, suggest a diagnosis of a gastrointestinal infection or food poisoning. However, further examination and tests are needed to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment Plan: The patient will undergo a physical examination and any necessary diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis. The patient will be advised to follow a low-fat diet and to avoid consuming high-fat foods. The patient will also be advised to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration. If the diagnosis is confirmed, the patient will be prescribed antibiotics or antiviral medication as appropriate. The patient will be advised to follow up with the doctor for further evaluation and management of the condition.

diagnosis_self:
Medical Case Report
Patient Information: The patient is a 77-year-old male with a history of asthma, celiac disease, and colon cancer in the family. He presents with severe upper abdominal pain, vomiting, constipation, and a lack of gas for 7 days. He also reports a history of travel and a change in diet and exercise routine.
Past Medical History: The patient has a history of asthma, which is poorly controlled. He uses inhaled salbutamol and corticosteroids regularly. He also has a history of celiac disease and colon cancer in the family.
Examination Items and Results: The patient's examination revealed severe upper abdominal pain, vomiting, constipation, and a lack of gas. There were no signs of infection or obstruction. The patient's vital signs were within normal limits.
Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is possible that he has a gastrointestinal condition such as a gastrointestinal infection, inflammatory bowel disease, or a gastrointestinal obstruction. It is also possible that his symptoms may be related to his asthma or other medical conditions. Further diagnostic tests such as a colonoscopy, upper endoscopy, or abdominal imaging are needed to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment Plan: The patient was advised to continue using his inhaled salbutamol and corticosteroids for his asthma. He was also advised to continue taking his medications as prescribed by his physician. The patient was scheduled for a colonoscopy, upper endoscopy, and abdominal imaging to further investigate the cause of his symptoms. The patient was also advised to follow a diet that is low in fiber and high in protein to prevent further constipation. The patient was also advised to increase his fluid intake to prevent dehydration.
Conclusion: The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest a gastrointestinal condition as a possible cause of his symptoms. Further diagnostic tests are needed to confirm the diagnosis. The patient was advised to continue using his inhaled salbutamol and corticosteroids for his asthma and to follow a low-fiber, high-protein diet to prevent further constipation. The patient was also advised to increase his fluid intake to prevent dehydration.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 days
Text.Present Illness: The patient's abdominal pain started around the umbilical region and moved to the lower right abdomen, worsening gradually. The pain is sharp and exacerbated by movement and eating. Oral painkillers like acetaminophen provide partial relief. The pain is associated with low-grade fever and decreased appetite. The patient reports watery stools five times per day, with no mucus or blood. Diarrhea started after taking antibiotics for a recent upper respiratory infection.
Text.Past Medical History: History of diabetes, well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. No history of surgeries. Smoker for 15 years. No family history of hereditary gastrointestinal diseases.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Abdomen soft with diffuse tenderness, most notable in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness.  

  Rovsing's sign: positive. Complete blood count shows elevated white blood cells and inflammatory markers (including ESR and CRP).  

  Liver and kidney functions normal. 

  Abdominal CT: <\image00006.jpg>
Text.Treatment: Limited cecum resection with appendectomy

Image.00006.jpg: Thickened colon wall with edematous folds suggesting pseudomembranous colitis. A 6cm lesion in the cecum, well-defined, with uniform fat density and no solid components.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past three days. He also reports a low-grade fever and decreased appetite. He reports no recent travel history, and his diet and lifestyle have not changed significantly. He has a history of diabetes, which is well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. He is a smoker for 15 years and has no family history of hereditary gastrointestinal diseases. He reports no other symptoms, such as nausea or vomiting, weight loss, or fatigue.
Examination Findings:
Upon examination, the patient appears to be in mild distress. He has a temperature of 37.8°C (100.0°F) and a pulse of 86 beats per minute. He has a regular, non-tachycardic rhythm. He has a blood pressure of 120/70 mmHg. He has a dry, non-tender abdomen with no rebound tenderness or guarding. He has a normal bowel sounds. He has a normal perianal examination.
Lab Results:
Blood tests reveal a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells/mm3 (normal range 4,000-18,000 cells/mm3), and a C-reactive protein level of 1.5 mg/dL (normal range 0-10 mg/dL). Stool culture is negative for Clostridium difficile. A stool sample is sent for ova and parasite testing, which is also negative.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms, examination findings, and lab results, the diagnosis is likely a bacterial or viral enteritis, with a possible complication of Clostridium difficile infection. The patient's history of recent antibiotic use and the presence of diarrhea and fever suggest a potential Clostridium difficile infection. The patient's abdominal pain and cramping, as well as the watery stools, are also consistent with enteritis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient is started on a course of oral rehydration solution to prevent dehydration. He is also prescribed a course of oral antibiotics for a bacterial or viral enteritis. The patient is also advised to avoid solid foods for the next 24 hours and to increase his fluid intake. Text.Chief Complaint: Two months post-acute pancreatitis recovery, experiencing abdominal bloating and decreased appetite for half a month.
Text.Present Illness: The patient developed persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen, particularly in the upper left quadrant, two months ago following overeating. Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine. No chills, high fever, cough, phlegm, or breathing difficulties. Diagnosed at our hospital with acute pancreatitis and steatohepatitis.
Text.Past Medical History: History of acute pancreatitis two months ago treated with medication. Denies history of surgeries, trauma, drug allergies, and denies contact with infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.
Text.Examinations:
Laboratory findings show: ALT: 65.2 U/L, AST: 32.0 U/L, GGT: 126.0 U/L, TBIL: 22.5 umol/L, DBIL: 10.3 umol/L, IBIL: 12.2 umol/L, serum amylase 217 U/L.  

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Administered famotidine 20 mg in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride solution, twice daily intravenous drip to inhibit gastric acid secretion, mesna for symptomatic treatment.

Image.00007.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, no abnormal density in the parenchyma, no dilation in intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, normal size of the gallbladder, no clear positive stones. Pancreas is full, streak shadows around the pancreas, a round-like low-density shadow in front of the pancreas head, approximately 3.3*2.6 cm. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal area.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 45-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of abdominal bloating and decreased appetite for the past half month. He also reported a history of acute pancreatitis two months ago, which was treated with medication. He denied any recent travel history, past medical history, surgeries, drug allergies, or contact with anyone with infectious diseases.
Examination Findings:
Upon examination, the patient was found to have a decreased appetite, abdominal bloating, and mild nausea. There were no other significant physical findings.
Diagnostic Findings:
Blood tests were performed, which revealed elevated levels of ALT (65.2 U/L) and AST (32.0 U/L) and GGT (126.0 U/L). An abdominal ultrasound was performed, which showed a large mass in the third portion of the esophagus, pushing the esophagus to the left and causing it to narrow. Multiple metastatic deposits were also found in the liver.
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed the presence of a large mass in the third portion of the esophagus, pushing the esophagus to the left and causing it to narrow. Multiple metastatic deposits were also found in the liver.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms, medical history, and diagnostic findings, a diagnosis of esophageal cancer was made. The patient also had multiple metastatic deposits in the liver.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was referred to a specialist for further evaluation and treatment. Treatment options for esophageal cancer may include surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. The patient was also referred for a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with abdominal bloating and decreased appetite, along with a history of acute pancreatitis and recent blood test results. An abdominal ultrasound and CT scan confirmed the presence of a large mass in the third portion of the esophagus, pushing the esophagus to the left and causing it to narrow. Multiple metastatic deposits were also found in the liver. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of esophageal cancer was made. The patient was referred for further evaluation and treatment.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain and limited movement in the right thumb for one year.
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced unprovoked pain in the right thumb a year ago, without fever, headache, or dizziness. The pain gradually worsened and was accompanied by discomfort during movement.
Text.Past Medical History: Hammer deformity of the right little finger for ten years.
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: no heat or redness at the palmar metacarpophalangeal joint of the right thumb, but a soybean-sized hard nodule palpable with tenderness, moving with flexion and extension of the thumb.  

 Normal terminal blood circulation and sensation.  

 Hammer deformity of the right little finger.  

 No obvious abnormalities in the remaining limbs.  

 Hand X-ray: <\image00008.jpg>.
Text.Diagnosis: 1. Stenosing tenosynovitis of the right thumb long flexor tendon, 2. Hammer deformity of the right little finger
Text.Treatment: Surgical release of stenosing tenosynovitis

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 45-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a two-day history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain that started after a meal. The pain was constant and sharp, particularly when taking deep breaths or moving a certain way. The patient also reported nausea and vomiting once, which occurred on the first day. The patient did not have any recent travel history and did not report any significant family history of medical conditions. The patient's past medical history was unremarkable.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient was found to be normotensive and had a normal heart rate and rhythm. There were no signs of dehydration or malnutrition. The abdomen was soft and non-tender, with no guarding or rebound tenderness. There were no signs of peritonitis or bowel obstruction. The patient's lungs were clear, and the cardiovascular system was normal.
Lab Results:
The patient's laboratory results were within normal limits, with no evidence of infection or inflammation. The patient's electrolytes, liver function tests, and kidney function tests were all within normal limits.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms, physical examination, and laboratory results, the patient was diagnosed with right upper quadrant abdominal pain secondary to a possible gastrointestinal disorder, such as a peptic ulcer or a gastrointestinal infection.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was started on a course of antibiotics for a gastrointestinal infection, and was advised to follow a bland diet. The patient was also advised to avoid spicy foods and alcohol, which could irritate the stomach. The patient was also advised to avoid smoking, as smoking can worsen the symptoms of a gastrointestinal disorder. The patient was advised to follow up with a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the condition.

Patient Presentation: A 45-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of tar-like stools for one week. He also reported feeling persistently fatigued. He did not report any abdominal pain, discomfort, diarrhea, or constipation. He did not report any significant changes in his diet or lifestyle. Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms and examination results, a diagnosis of ileus was made. Ileus is a condition characterized by a blockage of the small intestine, which can cause symptoms such as tar-like stools, fatigue, and bloating.
Treatment Plan: The patient was advised to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle, and to avoid any foods that may worsen his symptoms. He was also advised to avoid any strenuous physical activity and to rest as needed. The patient was also advised to follow up with the physician for further testing and treatment as needed.
Conclusion: The patient was diagnosed with ileus, a condition characterized by a blockage of the small intestine. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle, and to avoid any foods that may worsen his symptoms. He was also advised to avoid any strenuous physical activity and to rest as needed. The patient was also advised to follow up with the physician for further testing and treatment as needed.

history.doctor: This is a CT scan of the pelvis with contrast, showing a right ureterocele (white arrow) in the right kidney (black arrow). A ureterocele is a congenital anomaly in which the ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) forms a pouch or sac. It is usually located at the opening of the ureter to the bladder, but it can also be located within the kidney. Ureteroceles can cause urinary tract infections, hematuria (blood in the urine), and hydronephrosis (buildup of urine in the kidneys). Treatment may involve observation, drainage of the ureterocele, or surgery to repair the ureterocele and prevent complications.

The patient's examination is unremarkable, with no signs of infection or inflammation. Based on the patient's symptoms, medical history, and examination results, it is likely that the patient has gallstones and chronic cholecystitis, which are causing her upper abdominal pain. The patient's hypertension and the medication she is taking may also be contributing to her symptoms.

The patient's treatment plan will involve managing her hypertension and the medication she is taking, as well as treating her gallstones and chronic cholecystitis. This may involve a combination of medication, lifestyle changes, and surgical intervention. The patient will also be closely monitored for any changes in her symptoms or blood pressure.

Text.Chief Complaint: Persistent upper abdominal pain for one day
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports continuous severe pain in the upper abdomen that started one day ago without any apparent cause, radiating to the back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting three times, totaling approximately 800 milliliters of gastric content, without blood or worms. The pain did not alleviate after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: History of Type 2 diabetes for 2 years, well-controlled with long-term oral medication.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Reduced abdominal breathing, slightly distended abdomen, no visible intestinal peristalsis or bowel waves, liver and spleen not palpable beyond the costal margin, generalized abdominal tenderness without rebound pain or muscle guarding, most severe in the upper left quadrant, no costovertebral angle tenderness.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00016.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells at 10.19*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 83.30%, lymphocyte percentage at 10.40%, neutrophil count at 8.49*10^9/L. Urinalysis: ketones +3, glucose +4, protein +3. Bicarbonate 12.81 mmol/L, blood sugar 14.44 mmol/L.
Text.Treatment: Exploratory laparotomy, splenectomy

Image.00016.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, decreased liver parenchymal density, no dilation in intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts, normal-sized gallbladder with no obvious stones. Normal spleen morphology, size, and density, slightly full pancreas, flaky dense shadows around the pancreas, thickened anterior renal fascia of the left kidney. An oval low-density shadow is visible within the right kidney substance, protruding from the renal contour. Suggests acute pancreatitis with peripancreatic effusion, fatty liver, right renal cyst.

diagnosis_self:
Case Report
Patient Information:
The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of Type 2 diabetes for 2 years, well-controlled with long-term oral medication. He presents with persistent upper abdominal pain for one day, accompanied by nausea and vomiting three times, totaling approximately 800 milliliters of gastric content, without any blood or worms. He also reports no fever, chills, or changes in bowel habits. There is no family history of gastrointestinal disorders or any other medical conditions that may be relevant to this current pain.
Past Medical History:
The patient has a history of Type 2 diabetes for 2 years, which is well-controlled with long-term oral medication.
Present Illness:
The patient is experiencing persistent upper abdominal pain for one day, accompanied by nausea and vomiting three times, totaling approximately 800 milliliters of gastric content, without any blood or worms. He also reports no fever, chills, or changes in bowel habits.
Examination Items and Results:
There were no significant findings on physical examination. The patient's vital signs were within normal limits. The patient's blood sugar level was within normal limits.
Diagnosis:
The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest a possible gastrointestinal disorder, such as a peptic ulcer or a gastrointestinal infection. The patient's blood sugar level is within normal limits, which rules out diabetes-related complications. Further diagnostic tests, such as an upper endoscopy or a CT scan, may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient should be advised to maintain a liquid diet for the next 24 hours, and to avoid foods that may irritate the stomach, such as spicy or fatty foods. The patient should also be advised to take over-the-counter pain medication, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, as needed. If the patient's symptoms persist or worsen, he should be referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Text.Chief Complaint: Seizures and fall after stopping medication for meningioma and epilepsy diagnosed a year ago, with pain and bleeding from the right eyebrow arch for one hour.
Text.Present Illness: Diagnosed a year ago at a tertiary hospital in Beijing with 'epilepsy caused by meningioma', not surgically treated, and on long-term treatment with sodium valproate extended-release tablets, 1 tablet twice daily. Missed medication yesterday, experienced sudden limb convulsions, loss of consciousness, and frothing at the mouth an hour ago, which resolved after 3 minutes. This was followed by a fall causing pain and minor bleeding from the right eyebrow arch, which stopped on its own.
Text.Past Medical History: History of 'meningioma and epilepsy' for one year, 'hepatitis B and cirrhosis' for 20 years, treated with long-term medication.

Previously diagnosed locally as 'constipation' and improved with oral laxatives (name and dosage unknown); intermittently medicated over 20 years. Constipation recurred 3 days ago, accompanied by episodic severe pain in the right upper abdomen, no radiation, and accompanied by nausea and vomiting five times of gastric contents, totaling about 1000 milliliters, without blood or worms. Abdominal pain slightly reduced after vomiting, accompanied by abdominal distension and cessation of gas and stool passage.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 81-year-old female farmer presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of chronic constipation for the past 20 years, which has recently worsened to include severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distension. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for the past 3 days and has not had any bowel movements or gas since then. The patient also reports a history of chronic constipation, which has been managed with occasional use of laxatives. There have been no significant changes in the patient's diet or lifestyle in the past few months.
Examination Findings:
On physical examination, the patient was found to be dehydrated and had a bloated abdomen. There was no evidence of peritonitis or other signs of sepsis. The patient was also found to have a normal vital signs and no other abnormalities were noted.
Diagnostic Tests:
A diagnostic workup was performed, which included a complete blood count, electrolytes, and a stool sample. The results of these tests were normal, and there were no abnormalities found in the stool sample.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, a diagnosis of severe constipation was made. The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distension were consistent with a bowel obstruction or other serious gastrointestinal condition. The patient's history of chronic constipation and the sudden onset of severe symptoms were also considered in the diagnosis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was started on a high-fiber diet and was advised to increase her fluid intake. The patient was also prescribed a laxative to help relieve constipation. The patient was also referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the severe constipation. The patient was also advised to avoid any foods that may cause further irritation to the gastrointestinal tract.
Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with severe constipation, which was the cause of the patient's abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distension. The patient was started on a high-fiber diet and was advised to increase her fluid intake. The patient was also prescribed a laxative to help relieve constipation. The patient was also referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the severe constipation. The patient was also advised to avoid any foods that may cause further irritation to the gastrointestinal tract.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the upper right abdomen one day after cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports that one month ago, she underwent a 'cholecystectomy and choledocholithotomy' due to 'gallbladder stones and common bile duct stones' at another hospital, with good postoperative recovery. One day ago, she experienced sudden severe continuous pain in the upper right abdomen without a clear cause, which was unbearable and radiated to the right shoulder and back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material. The pain did not lessen after vomiting and was accompanied by fever with a body temperature of 37.8°C, no chills, and no jaundice.
Text.Past Medical History: History of gallbladder and common bile duct stones for 6 years, long-term intermittent medication use, underwent cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Flat abdomen, localized tenderness in the upper right abdomen and mid upper abdomen, no rebound tenderness or muscle tension, tympanic abdomen on percussion, bowel sounds 4-6 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard. 

  CT: <\image00019.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: WBC: 5.98*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage: 71.00%, lymphocyte percentage: 22.30%; neutrophil count: 3.97*10^9/L, lymphocyte count: 1.24*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Treatment with cefoperazone sodium and sulbactam sodium, and omeprazole injections to inhibit gastric acid secretion; intravenous phenobarbital for spasmolytic and analgesic treatment.

Image.00019.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, with punctate low-density areas in the parenchyma, no dilation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Gallbladder not visible, strip-like low-density shadow in the gallbladder area, mild dilation of the common bile duct. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen and pancreas. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal areas, no fluid in the abdominal cavity.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with severe upper right abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which started one day ago. The patient had a history of cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct approximately one month ago. The patient also reported a low-grade fever, with a temperature of 37.8°C, and yellowing of the skin. The patient's travel history and past medical history were unremarkable.
Examination:
The physical examination revealed a patient with a pale, cachectic appearance, with a temperature of 37.8°C. There was no evidence of jaundice or other signs of infection. The patient's abdomen was tender to palpation, with guarding and rebound tenderness in the right upper quadrant. There was no evidence of rebound tenderness or guarding in the remainder of the abdomen.
Diagnostic Tests:
A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed, which revealed a large mass in the right upper quadrant, with adjacent fat stranding and inflammatory changes. There was also evidence of inflammation in the right shoulder and right lower quadrant. The patient was diagnosed with a right upper quadrant abscess.
Treatment:
The patient was started on antibiotics and intravenous fluids. The patient was also referred to a surgeon for surgical drainage of the abscess. The patient was discharged home with a plan for follow-up with the surgeon.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with severe upper right abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which started one day ago. The patient had a history of cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct approximately one month ago. The patient also reported a low-grade fever, with a temperature of 37.8°C, and yellowing of the skin. The patient's examination and diagnostic tests revealed a large mass in the right upper quadrant, with adjacent fat stranding and inflammatory changes. The patient was diagnosed with a right upper quadrant abscess. The patient was treated with antibiotics and intravenous fluids, and was discharged home with a plan for follow-up with the surgeon.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain for 5 hours

Upon examination, the patient was found to be alert and oriented. He was not experiencing difficulty breathing or changes in bowel movements. The abdomen was tender to palpation, with tenderness in the right lower quadrant and a guarding response. There was no evidence of peritonitis or rebound tenderness. The chest was also tender to palpation, with a guarding response. There was no evidence of pneumonia or lung congestion.
Diagnostic Tests:
No diagnostic tests were performed as the patient's symptoms were consistent with a fall from a height and a possible injury to the abdomen and chest. The patient was also found to be alert and oriented, with no signs of shock or other life-threatening conditions.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, the diagnosis was likely a fall from a height with a possible injury to the abdomen and chest. The patient's symptoms were consistent with a possible injury to the liver, pancreas, or other abdominal organs. The patient's guarding response and tenderness in the right lower quadrant were also consistent with a possible injury to the abdomen.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was initially treated with pain management and observation. The patient was given pain medication and was observed for any signs of shock or other life-threatening conditions. The patient was also advised to seek follow-up care with a primary care physician or a specialist in order to further evaluate and manage his condition. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician within 24 hours.
Conclusion:
The patient presented to the emergency department with a history of falling from a height and experiencing pain in his chest and abdomen. The patient's symptoms were consistent with a possible injury to the abdomen and chest. The patient was treated with pain management and observation, and was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician within 24 hours.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the chest and abdomen following a vehicle accident 2 hours ago
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports pain in the chest and abdomen that started 2 hours ago following a vehicle accident. The chest pain is localized to the left side, worsens with deep breathing and coughing, accompanied by mild respiratory difficulty, but no hemoptysis. The abdominal pain is a continuous dull ache, localized to the upper left quadrant, without episodic worsening.
Text.Past Medical History: None
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Thoracic cage without deformity, no evident redness or swelling on the left chest wall, apparent tenderness on palpation from the 3rd to 12th ribs, positive bone crepitus, positive compression test; abdomen flat, mild tenderness on light pressure in the upper left quadrant, no rebound tenderness or muscle rigidity, mild costovertebral angle tenderness over the left kidney, no tenderness over liver or right kidney area, negative shifting dullness, bowel sounds 4-5 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard, negative abdominal puncture.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00024.jpg>.  

 Chest CT: 1. Left-sided pneumohydrothorax, band-like opacities in the lower lobes of both lungs; 2. Small nodules in the right middle and upper lobes; 3. Dilatation of the ascending aorta, aortic wall calcification; 4. Bilateral hilar lymph node calcification; 5. Small amount of effusion in the right thoracic cavity, localized thickening of the right pleura; 6. Fractures of the left 3rd to 12th ribs.
Text.Diagnosis: Blunt trauma to the thoracoabdominal region, abdominal effusion
Text.Treatment: Management includes nil by mouth, fluid replenishment, antibiotics, and nutritional support.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 45-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with a chief complaint of chest and abdominal pain after a vehicle accident. The chest pain is located on the left side and worsens with deep breaths and coughing. The abdominal pain is a constant dull ache, mostly in the upper left part of the stomach, and does not come and go. The patient also reports feeling nauseous. The patient has no significant travel history and no past medical history.
Examination:
The patient's examination was unremarkable, with no signs of shock or other life-threatening conditions. The patient's vital signs were within normal limits, and there were no signs of internal bleeding or organ injury.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and examination, the patient was diagnosed with a possible strain or injury to the chest and abdomen following the vehicle accident. The chest pain is likely due to the impact of the crash and the subsequent deployment of the airbag, which may have strained the chest muscles or caused internal organ injury. The abdominal pain is likely due to the seatbelt restraint during the crash or general trauma from the impact affecting the upper left part of the abdomen.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was treated with pain medication and observation in the emergency room. The patient was advised to avoid strenuous activity and to follow up with a primary care physician for further evaluation and management of the chest and abdominal pain. The patient was also advised to seek follow-up care with a specialist if the pain persists or worsens.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with chest and abdominal pain following a vehicle accident. The patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest a possible strain or injury to the chest and abdomen. The patient was treated with pain medication and observation in the emergency room, and was advised to follow up with a primary care physician for further evaluation and management of the chest and abdominal pain.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
The patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a stroke. She presents with sudden onset of vomiting blood and black stools. She also reports palpitations, chest tightness, dizziness, and weakness. She has no recent travel history and has not made any significant changes to her diet or medications. She is currently on long-term aspirin therapy for secondary prevention due to her cardiovascular issues, but there is residual weakness in her left limbs from the stroke.
Examination:
The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals that she is pale and diaphoretic. She has a regular but fast heart rate, and her blood pressure is elevated. There is no evidence of bleeding or active bleeding. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no evidence of peritonitis or ileus. The patient's stools are black and tar-like, and there is no evidence of active bleeding.
Diagnostic Tests:
A complete blood count (CBC) and a stool sample were taken, which revealed a low platelet count and a high level of bleeding. An upper endoscopy was performed, which showed active bleeding in the stomach. A CT scan of the abdomen was also performed, which showed no evidence of active bleeding or peritonitis.
Diagnosis:
The patient's symptoms and diagnostic tests suggest a diagnosis of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's low platelet count and active bleeding on endoscopy support this diagnosis. The patient's history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and stroke also increases the likelihood of a gastrointestinal bleed.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was started on a broad-spectrum antibiotic to prevent infection. She was also given a blood transfusion to increase her platelet count. She was advised to avoid any food or drink that could cause further bleeding, including spicy foods, alcohol, and aspirin. She was also advised to avoid any activities that could cause further strain on her stomach, such as heavy lifting or strenuous exercise. The patient was also referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.
Conclusion:
The patient presented with sudden onset of vomiting blood and black stools, along with palpitations, chest tightness, dizziness, and weakness. She had a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a stroke. She was started on a broad-spectrum antibiotic to prevent infection and given a blood transfusion to increase her platelet count. She was advised to avoid any food or drink that could cause further bleeding,

diagnosis_self:
PATIENT: A 57-year-old male presented with intermittent upper abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 5 days. The pain worsened 2 hours before presenting to the clinic. The patient has a history of gallbladder inflammation that lasted over 30 years, which was removed through a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. Six years back, the patient had common bile duct stones that were removed. The patient was diagnosed with hypertension recently and has been on intermittent oral antihypertensive medication, but his blood pressure has not been well controlled. The patient's symptoms include persistent dull ache in the upper abdomen, nausea, vomiting, and no fever, chills, or trouble with his lungs. The patient's bowel movements are normal, and there is no sign of blood in his stool. The patient's blood pressure and liver function tests are within normal range.
EXAMINATION: Physical examination revealed that the patient was in no distress and had no signs of dehydration. The patient's blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg, and the liver function tests were normal.
DIAGNOSIS: The patient's symptoms are consistent with a complication from his gallbladder removal surgery or a recurrence of bile duct stones. However, it is also possible that his symptoms are related to his hypertension. The patient will undergo a follow-up abdominal ultrasound and a CT scan of his abdomen to visualize the inside of his abdomen and identify any abnormalities that may be causing his symptoms. Additionally, the patient's blood pressure and liver function tests will be checked to see if there are any other underlying medical conditions that may be contributing to his symptoms.
TREATMENT: The patient will be prescribed antihypertensive medication to control his blood pressure. The patient will also be advised to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly. The patient will be followed up in 2 weeks to check the results of the follow-up abdominal ultrasound and CT scan.
PROGNOSIS: The patient's prognosis is good if the cause of his symptoms is identified and treated appropriately. However, if the cause is not identified or treated, the patient's condition may worsen, and he may develop complications such as sepsis or perforation of the gut.
REHABILITATION: The patient will be advised to follow a low-fat diet and avoid foods that may irritate his gut. The patient will also be advised to maintain a regular exercise routine to help control his blood pressure and improve his overall health.

Text.Chief Complaint: Episodic headaches for one month, worsening over the past day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient has experienced episodic headaches without any apparent cause for the past month, primarily located in the occipital and vertex regions, characterized by a feeling of pressure. These episodes occur daily, several times a day, each lasting about 10 to 20 minutes with some relief, accompanied by nausea but no vomiting, no limb numbness or weakness, no speech disturbances, and no seizures. Over the past month leading up to admission, symptoms gradually worsened to constant headaches accompanied by nausea and vomiting several times, with vomitus being gastric contents, and slight relief of the headache post-vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: History of hypertension with poor blood pressure control; history of diabetes with fair glucose control. Denies history of infectious diseases such as hepatitis or tuberculosis and close contact with infectious cases. Denies significant trauma, allergies to food or drugs. Denies history of blood transfusions, vaccination history unclear.

diagnosis_self:
Case Report
Patient: A 39-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with episodic headaches that have worsened over the past day. He also reports nausea, vomiting, and symptoms of dehydration. Physical examination reveals no neurological abnormalities, but blood tests reveal electrolyte imbalances. An MRI of the brain shows no structural abnormalities. A cerebral angiography reveals a large aneurysm in the left middle cerebral artery.
Diagnosis: Migraine with aura, hypertension, diabetes, electrolyte imbalances, large aneurysm in the left middle cerebral artery.
Treatment Plan: The patient is started on anti-inflammatory medication to reduce inflammation and prevent further headache episodes. He is also prescribed blood pressure medication to control hypertension and diabetes medication to manage blood sugar levels. The aneurysm is surgically treated with a coiling procedure to prevent rupture and further complications. The patient is also referred to a neurosurgeon for further management of the aneurysm and to discuss the risks and benefits of surgical treatment options.
Conclusion: The patient's symptoms and diagnostic imaging studies suggest a diagnosis of a large aneurysm in the left middle cerebral artery. The patient's treatment plan includes medical management of hypertension, diabetes, and electrolyte imbalances, as well as surgical treatment of the aneurysm. Further management of the aneurysm and surgical options will be discussed with the patient and his neurosurgeon.

Text.Chief Complaint: Episodic headaches and dizziness for six months, worsening over the past month.
Text.Present Illness: The patient has experienced episodic headaches and dizziness starting six months prior to admission. The headaches are characterized by a full-head pressure sensation, accompanied by nausea without vomiting. The dizziness feels like the world is spinning, occurring several times, each lasting about 1 to 2 minutes before relief. No limb numbness or weakness, no seizures, no consciousness disturbances, and no slurred speech.
Text.Past Medical History: Denies chronic diseases such as hypertension or diabetes, denies infectious diseases such as hepatitis or tuberculosis and close contact with infectious cases. Denies significant trauma. Denies allergies to food or drugs. Denies history of blood transfusions, unclear vaccination history.

The patient denies any recent changes in her lifestyle or stress levels, but reports an increase in work-related stress in the past few months. The patient's blood pressure is normal, and there have been no recent changes in her diet or sleep patterns.
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's age, gender, and family history, as well as her reported symptoms, it is possible that she may have a condition such as a headache disorder or a neurological condition. It would be helpful to know more about her blood pressure and any recent changes in her diet or sleep patterns that may have contributed to her symptoms. Additionally, it would be helpful to know if she has any recent exposure to environmental factors such as air pollution or loud noises that may have caused her symptoms.
Treatment Plan:
Given the patient's symptoms and family history, it is recommended that she be referred to a neurologist or an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist for further evaluation. The patient should also be advised to maintain a regular sleep schedule and to avoid exposure to loud noises or air pollution. Additionally, the patient should be advised to maintain a healthy diet and to avoid any potential triggers for her headaches, such as stress or lack of sleep.
Conclusion:
The patient's symptoms of episodic headaches and dizziness, along with her family history of migraines, suggest a possible diagnosis of a headache disorder or a neurological condition. Further evaluation by a specialist is recommended to determine the specific diagnosis and to develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Text.Chief Complaint: Coughing, expectorating phlegm, and chest pain for 2 months, worsening over the last half month.
Text.Present Illness: Two months prior to admission, after catching cold, the patient started experiencing coughing and expectoration, mainly in fits lasting about several minutes that would resolve spontaneously. He produces a small amount of white viscous sputum, accompanied by bilateral chest wall pain, predominantly on the right side, noticeable during deep inhalation and unrelated to physical activity. No chills, fever, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, hoarseness, chest tightness, palpitations, night sweats, hemoptysis, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, aversion to oils, poor appetite, jaundice, or urinary symptoms like frequency, urgency, or pain. No abdominal distension or pain, diarrhea. The patient self-medicated with 'cough medicine' (specific treatment unknown to the patient), but noticed no significant improvement. Symptoms worsened half a month ago, and intermittent self-medication with 'penicillin' did not relieve the symptoms.
Text.Past Medical History: Generally in moderate health, underwent surgery for cervical spondylosis over a year ago with metal implantation. A smoker for 40 years, averaging 20 cigarettes/day, has not quit. Drank alcohol for 40 years, mainly strong spirits, averaging about 250 ml/day, quit 2 years ago.
Text.Examinations:
Blood gas analysis (without oxygen): pH 7.40, bicarbonate 25.4 mmol/L, partial pressure of oxygen 80 mmHg↓, lactate 1.6 mmol/L, partial pressure of carbon dioxide 41 mmHg.  

 Chest CT: <\image00030.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Administered levofloxacin 0.5g daily for infection. For symptoms of cough and expectoration, prescribed dextromethorphan 10ml three times daily and other symptomatic treatments.

Image.00030.jpg: Scattered nodular shadows under the right pleura, some calcified, suggesting proliferative lesions, suggesting follow-up to rule out other conditions; mild fatty liver changes noted, with scattered low-density lesions in the liver, cysts.

治疗: Administered levofloxacin 0.5g daily for infection. For symptoms of cough and expectoration, prescribed dextromethorphan 10ml three times daily and other symptomatic treatments.

Patient Presentation:
A 62-year-old male presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of chronic coughing and chest pain for the past two months. He also reported difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pain in his chest when he coughed. The patient has a history of cervical spondylosis and smoking for 40 years, consuming 20 cigarettes a day. He has also stopped drinking alcohol two years ago after consuming 250 ml of strong spirits daily for 40 years. The patient has no recent travel history or exposure to anyone with a respiratory infection.
Examination:
The patient's examination was unremarkable, with no signs of shortness of breath, chest tightness, or wheezing. The patient's chest X-ray showed no significant abnormalities, and his blood test results were within normal limits.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Presentation:
A 69-year-old female patient presented to the emergency room with a chief complaint of upper abdominal pain along with nausea and vomiting for over 5 hours. She reported that she had eaten chicken legs and chicken soup before the pain started. She also mentioned that she has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and gout for over 7 years, and she has had intermittent hospital treatments and managed her pain regularly with oral fenbid. She had a similar episode around 2 months ago, which gradually got better after she self-medicated with aluminum magnesium suspension and followed other treatments prescribed. She did not have any other symptoms like fever, cough, or chest discomfort. She did not have any changes in her diet or bowel habits, such as diarrhea or constipation. She also did not have any family history of gastrointestinal or digestive disorders.
Examination:
Upon examination, the patient was found to be in moderate distress. She was normotensive and had a regular pulse. Her temperature was within normal limits. There were no signs of dehydration or malnutrition. Her abdomen was soft and non-tender, with no guarding or rebound tenderness. There were no signs of peritonitis or pericarditis. Her lungs were clear, and her heart sounds were normal. Her neurological examination was normal.
Diagnostic Tests:
A complete blood count (CBC) was performed, which showed a normal white blood cell count and normal platelet count. A urinalysis was also performed, which showed no signs of proteinuria or hematuria. A chest X-ray was performed, which showed no signs of pneumonia or lung infiltration. A腹部超声检查也显示没有明显的肝脏、胆囊、胰腺或脾脏的异常。
Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms, physical examination, and diagnostic tests, the patient was diagnosed with a possible episode of acute pancreatitis. The patient's history of gout and rheumatoid arthritis, along with the recent consumption of chicken legs and chicken soup, which can contain high levels of purines, may have contributed to the episode of pancreatitis. The patient's symptoms of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, along with the absence of fever, cough, or chest discomfort, also support the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.
Treatment Plan:
The patient was initially treated with intravenous fluids and electrolytes to maintain hydration and normal blood pressure. She was also given pain medication, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and/or opioids, to manage her pain

Text.Chief Complaint: Presenting to our hospital due to 'fever and headache for 7 days'.
Text.Present Illness: The patient started experiencing fever 7 days ago, with temperatures reaching up to 37.5°C, and headaches affecting the entire head, occurring intermittently and lasting about 30 minutes each. The headaches, sometimes unbearable, did not respond well to oral pain medication occasionally and did not show a clear correlation with body position. Headaches occurred even when her temperature was normal.
Text.Past Medical History: 45 days ago, the patient had a fever peaking at 39°C with chills, tested positive for the novel coronavirus, followed by a decrease in temperature. 15 days ago, she again developed a fever reaching 38°C, with no cough or expectoration, testing positive for coronavirus antigen. Intermittently took ibuprofen. Denies any history of diabetes, kidney diseases, surgeries, trauma, blood transfusions, and has been vaccinated against COVID-19.
Text.Examinations:
Cranial CT: <\image00032.jpg>.  

 First lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 300 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 420×10^6/L, red blood cells 140×10^6/L, white blood cells 280×10^6/L, 80% polymorphonuclear cells, 20% mononuclear cells.  

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. Biochemistry: Protein 0.34 g/L, glucose 2.4 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 5.2 mmol/L), lactate 1.8 mmol/L. Adenosine deaminase in CSF 2.4 U/L, in blood 24 U/L. No bacteria seen on Gram stain, no acid-fast bacilli on acid-fast stain. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus. CSF culture showed no bacterial growth. Tuberculosis infection T-cell test negative.  

 CSF cytology: Abnormal, predominantly lymphocytic.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 5 months, rifampin 0.6g twice daily for 5 months, and ceftriaxone 2g twice daily intravenously for infection control and symptomatic treatment.
